primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God establishes His kingdom by reversing the status of the poor and rich through the substitutionary work of Christ, enabling the believer to blossom under a new 'Coach'.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ was reversing places with us
He gave up his riches and became poor so that we... might become rich
God walks with you through that suffering to turn you into someone like Jesus

object.identificatie: The Kingdom of God (Restoration of human potential and unity)
tekstueel_bewijs: you enter into his realm... and you blossom
the blessings of the salvation of the kingdom
yours is the kingdom of God
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is invited to identify as the Receiver (spiritually bankrupt) rather than the Subject.

tekstueel_bewijs: through the gospel it creates a cadre of people
helper.rol_van_god: God is the primary Subject and the source of Help.
helper.rol_van_geest: Indwelling power that allows the kingdom to go 'deeper'.

tegenstander.identificatie: The Kingdom of this World / Pride (Middle-class spirit)
tekstueel_bewijs: the kingdom of this world... power, material comfort, success, and recognition
middle class in spirit person says, 'I don’t need your charity'
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but an entire 'operating system' that leads to spiritual death and 'wanting to kill yourself'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer, having received the kingdom, now acts to serve the poor and obey the King.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Saved Sinner)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Justice, service to the poor, and personal obedience.
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly rooted in the success of the primary program (soteriology). One cannot serve the poor without first being 'poor in spirit'.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God → Salvation/Kingdom → The Poor in Spirit

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus Christ was reversing places with us.
God came and saved you with his radical charity.
He emptied himself and became human.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: You turn to Jesus Christ as your Savior.

voorbeelden: Christians are to be poor in spirit.
The Bible says you should tithe.
Lord, I want more and more people... to know.
I want to show you what the kingdom of God is.
You need to know the rest of the Bible.
You can enter in when you’re born again.
Through his poverty we might become rich.
God walks with you... to turn you into someone like Jesus.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the 'Pouvoir' (Power/Ability) granted by Christ's substitution. It acknowledges the hearer's inability ('spiritual bankruptcy') and provides the competence through Grace.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (the woes of the world) to ~S1 (the middle-class spirit) to ~S2 (admitting bankruptcy) to S1 (receiving Christ's riches).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved through the 'Great Reversal' of the Cross, where Christ takes S2 so the hearer can move from ~S2 to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The 'woes' are described as a 'rotten practical joke' that leads to despair.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is fundamentally theocentric. While it contains ethical imperatives, they are strictly subordinated to the narrative of Christ’s substitutionary work.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Help me to be more obedient than ever.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ was reversing places with us. He gets what we deserve so we get what he deserves.
The things of this world will never satisfy you... you suddenly realize you want to kill yourself.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures are not used as moral examples; rather, the 'Poor' are a category of receivers.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon presents Jesus not as an example of how to be poor, but as the one whose poverty creates our wealth.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and humility (shattering of the 'middle-class' ego).
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by grace alone through faith.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'What it is' (Soteriology) to 'How it relates to prayer' (Ethics/Sanctification) is logically maintained through the lens of the Cross.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'doing what I say' and 'spiritual bankruptcy' is resolved by defining obedience as 'digging down to the rock' of Christ's love.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ was reversing places with us... he gets what we deserve so we get what he deserves.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (implied through the 'Gospel') transforms the heart's priorities from power to love.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as a 'middle-class' self-sufficiency that is actually a state of bankruptcy.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the primary Subject of the salvific narrative, placing the hearer in the role of the 'Poor' Receiver.

identificatie_herstel.strategie: Maintain the 'spiritual bankruptcy' identification to prevent the hearer from sliding into the 'Subject-Hero' role of the secondary program.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Increase Pouvoir (the current work of the Spirit).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Explicitly mention the Holy Spirit as the Helper who provides the 'Pouvoir-faire' for the secondary program.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Strongly intensified through the Heimel quote.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The current structure (Definition -> Contrast -> Substitution -> Application) is a model of grace-oriented homiletics.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a textbook example of how to use the Actantial Model to subvert moralism. By redefining 'poor' as a spiritual actant role (Receiver), the preacher prevents the Beatitudes from becoming a new Law.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Coach' metaphor; Greimas shows that the metaphor functions to establish God as the 'Sender' of a new culture.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek 'laugh'; Greimas shows how 'laughing' (gloating) serves as an 'Opponent' to the Kingdom's value system.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the 'Great Reversal' is actually a 'Subject-Switch' where Christ takes the actantial role of the 'Woe-Receiver' so the hearer can take the role of 'Blessing-Receiver'.

appendices.notities: The sermon effectively uses the 'Coach' metaphor to explain the 'Sender' role in a way that resonates with a non-monarchical audience.
